awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Summer Undergraduate Research Opportunity in Chemistry (SUROC) at UNC Chapel Hill
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is located in Chapel Hill, NC. It supports the training of 29 students in total for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. The principal investigators are Gerald Meyer and Leslie Hicks. This site is supported by the Division of Chemistry in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate. Students engage in a diverse set of research projects in chemistry, ranging from catalysis to solar energy conversion. Alongside hands-on research, students also participate in learning modules on ethics, communication, and entrepreneurship that includes site visits to a large industrial company and a small startup company in the Research Triangle Park of North Carolina. Taking part in cutting-edge research and tailored learning modules, students gain an appreciation for the subtleties of fundamental chemistry research and are in a position to make informed decisions about their career path. Students with limited access to research opportunities are especially recruited.

The participants benefit from mentors who are international leaders in their field and work in state-of the art facilities on topical problems with far-reaching impact in chemistry. The participants engage in cutting edge research and have the opportunity to make meaningful contributions in projects related to catalysis, polymer design and synthesis, solar energy conversion, redox biology, and nanotechnology. Through mentoring and peer interaction, students gain skills in efficient and effective use of scientific research tools, critical reading of scientific literature, design and implementation of experiments, and in written and oral communication for various audiences. Completion of this program enhances the research and mentoring experiences for undergraduate students who may not otherwise have such an opportunity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The REU at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, SUROC (Summer Undergraduate Research Opportunities in Chemistry), provides research opportunities to students to chemistry majors who might not otherwise be able to participate in authentic chemistry research. It focuses on rising juniors and seniors who identify with underrepresented demographics, including those enrolled at primarily undergraduate or under-resourced institutions to improve access to resources and opportunities in the field. To inspire participants to continue their education with a post-graduate degree, the program provides students with experiences to reinforce their laboratory skills, research skills, and collaboration skills while also enhancing their confidence and know-how as they move on in their academic / professional lives. Each student completes an individual research project which they then present in a poster session at the end of the program. Students are provided support through the ten-week program via a graduate student (or postdoctoral scholar) mentor, a faculty mentor, summer coordinator, program Co-PIs, and university resources. Given these specific goals, the overall goal of the program is to contribute to the movement towards a more equitable environment in the STEM workforce.

 

SUROC students are placed in faculty labs that match their stated interests as closely as possible, where UNC faculty span research areas including analytical, biological, inorganic, organic, physical and polymer/materials as well as interdisciplinary science. In addition to their faculty mentors, each SUROC student also had a graduate (or postdoctoral) mentor. Graduate mentors attend a mentor workshop before the program begins where they are provided with clear expectations of the goals of the program as well as their roles in supporting undergraduates from underresourced institutions. SUROC students are given an independent research project with a specific goal or hypothesis and are taught the necessary techniques to address the goal or hypothesis over the course of the summer program, culminating in a poster session in the last week.

 

For each of the summers of 2019, 2022, 2023 and (thanks to no-cost extension) 2024, eight undergraduate students arrived at UNC in May, completed safety training, learned a variety of lab techniques, completed experiments, summarized results, and presented a poster presentation at a research symposium ten weeks later. The students participated in professional development seminars offered by campus partners UNC Graduate School and the UNC School of Medicine Office of Graduate Education, including: the application process for graduate school; a graduate student panel; research ethics; CV development; and personal statement workshop. They toured UNC facilities including the Mass Spec and NMR cores, and they learned about scientific entrepreneurship from a member of the Chemistry Department faculty who has started two companies based on their research. Students visited two chemical industries, one small start-up and another company, both in nearby Research Triangle Park, to get a glimpse into chemical industry. Weekly breakfast meetings with SUROC PI/coordinator(s) provided opportunities to build cohesiveness among the students and confirm that research was proceeding smoothly. Social events ensured a strong sense of camaraderie among the students – and their lab mentors - including a Durham Bulls baseball game, a trip to Morehead Planetarium & Science Center, the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, Duke Gardens, and other local points of interest. Additional social events allowed participants to mingle with summer visitors on campus for other research programs.

 

Over the timespan of the grant, 32 students participated in the summer program: 50% were female and 87% identified as underrepresented minorities. As of Fall 2024, 31% of SUROC participants are still completing their undergraduate degrees in chemistry, with the majority of those planning to pursue graduate education in chemistry or another STEM field; another 50% have graduated and begun doctoral programs in chemistry or a related field; and 6% are currently in the STEM workforce. The intellectual merit of this program is that these students advanced chemical knowledge through research while gaining the hands-on lab skills and mentoring necessary to pursue graduate school. The broader impacts of this program are that it was successful in broadening the STEM workforce by inspiring students from diverse backgrounds and limited opportunities to pursue chemistry.
